name: porter
description: App artifacts, tools, configs, and logic packaged as distributable installer

repo.name: porter
repo.description: Porter enables you to package your application artifact, client tools, configuration and deployment logic together as an installer that you can distribute, and install with a single command.

readme.summary: The README provides good high-level clarity about what Porter does but completely lacks installation instructions, quick start examples, and any practical getting-started content, redirecting everything to the external website.
readme.top_issue: No installation instructions whatsoever - users cannot actually install or use Porter from reading this README alone

injection_risks.description: The use of os.Args[1:] could potentially lead to command injection if not properly sanitized.
The getCalledCommand function uses os.Args[1:] which could be vulnerable to command injection attacks if the input is not validated.

critical_findings: Potential command injection vulnerability in cmd/exec/main.go and cmd/porter/main.go
security.summary: The code has some potential security issues, including command injection vulnerabilities and lack of input validation, but overall it appears to be well-structured and follows good practices.

common_complaints: Unclear error messages and excessive verbosity in output
Signal handling issues (CTRL+C not stopping running processes)
File naming conflicts causing unexpected behavior
Configuration management complexity for multi-environment setups
Missing features for CLI management of configuration
sentiment.summary: Porter shows moderate community health with active maintenance and a mix of legitimate bug reports and feature requests, though some issues remain open for extended periods indicating potential prioritization challenges.

communication.summary: The responses are generally clear and helpful, showing a good level of technical depth and patience with contributors.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite last commit being recent (suggests repository was archived or abandoned after final update)
174 open issues with no resolution activity
No closed issues in past 6 months indicates no maintenance or bug fixing
Zero merged PRs in past 6 months shows no active development or community contributions being integrated
No active contributors in past 6 months
Unknown last release suggests release process has stopped
positive_signals: Recent commit timestamp indicates repository exists and was updated at some point
maintenance.summary: The porter project appears abandoned with zero maintenance activity over the past 6 months despite 174 unresolved issues and no contributor engagement.

governance.summary: The governance documentation indicates a clear path for contributor progression, documented decision-making processes, and multiple maintainers with merge rights, reducing the risk of bus factor.

project_metrics.description: Porter enables you to package your application artifact, client tools, configuration and deployment logic together as an installer that you can distribute, and install with a single command.

analysis_summary.doc_summary: The README provides a good overview of the package's purpose and features, but lacks clear installation instructions and troubleshooting guidance.
concerns: Docs: Lack of clear installation instructions
Community: Porter default error messages are too verbose for an installer experience
Security: Potential command injection vulnerability in cmd/exec/main.go and cmd/porter/main.go
highlights: High number of commits in the past six months (188)
A significant number of merged PRs in the past six months (101)
